Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Joint Adaptation of Multiple Cognitive Systems without Explicit Coordination

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Cognitive wireless systems are a collection of wireless network entities that are able to adapt intelligently to the environment through observation, exploration and learning. This project designs methods for cognitive radio systems to compete for inhomogeneous spectrum resources and to establish, without explicit coordination, a spectrum etiquette. Each system's resource utilization strategy must be decided with only imperfect information of other systems' actions, and the resulting adaptations must discourage any one system from manipulating the agreed spectrum etiquette. The framework of dynamic games with imperfect private monitoring is adopted to design coexistence mechanisms for cognitive radio systems sharing inhomogeneous resources and to analyze the stability, robustness, complexity, and convergence of these mechanisms. This work directly impacts the development and standardization of frequency agile wireless systems that can more efficiently use the available spectrum to support increasing demand for ubiquitous wireless connectivity at high data rates. The project is a collaborative effort between researchers in the US (at Virginia Tech and the University of Houston) and Finland (at the University of Oulu). This work will extend the state of the art in cognitive system adaptations by incorporating the ability to: efficiently adapt under imperfect information; fairly share inhomogeneous resources; and discourage manipulation of resource use by selfish adversaries. Results will be disseminated in high impact journals and conferences; the designed coexistence mechanisms will also be presented to industry and regulators in the US and Europe.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project studied cognitive radio systems that coexist, compete and share resources in a wireless network, forming a large-scale complex system. Unlike much of the recent research on the topic, we paid particular attention to conflicts that may arise among multiple cognitive radio systems due to the non-homogeneity of the available resources. For instance, some spectrum bands may be more desirable for opportunistic use than others, due to favorable channel conditions or because of less frequent presence of incumbent users in these bands. One of the outcomes of this project is the design of a channel selection strategy to be adopted by each cognitive radio that achieves a symmetric Nash equilibrium.

The second area of focus was the design of intelligent adaptation systems for cognitive radios under imperfect information.  In an environment where multiple cognitive radio systems coexist, any adaptation by one may trigger adaptations by all others. For efficient co-existence, each autonomous cognitive radio system is required to infer the actions of other systems based on noisy feedback (imperfect signals). We consider two sources of imperfect information: partial observability and sensing errors. Partial observability refers to situations where cognitive radios are unable to distinguish the presence of the incumbents on the channel from that of other cognitive radios making secondary use of spectrum.  This type of imperfect information occurs, for example, when cognitive radio systems adopt simple sensing techniques such as energy detection.  Another outcome of the project was the design of two channel selection strategies under full and partial observability of channel activity. We evaluated the performance of our proposed strategies through both mathematical analysis and simulation. We proved that both proposed strategies converge to a stable orthogonal channel allocation when the missed detection rate is zero. The simulation results validate the efficiency and robustness of our proposed strategies even with a non-zero probability of missed detection.

For cognitive radios to become widely commercially deployed, they must be robust to imperfections of their observations of the wireless environment. Our research contributes in that direction by doing away with the common (but unrealistic) assumption of perfect observation of past incumbent activity and past channel conditions, to devise solutions under the much more likely situation where cognitive radio only have a partial, imperfect view of the environment in which they operate.

Other, broader impacts of the project have included substantial international collaboration with researchers in Finland; the graduate student funded by the grant had the opportunity to spend two weeks working in the laboratory of our collaborators at the University of Oulu.
